  • exposure to risk
  • timing and delay
  • access to appeals

Rules that strengthen one party's litigation position shift settlement in that party's favor, even when substantive law is unchanged.

Litigation and Ex Ante Incentives

The effects of litigation extend beyond disputes that actually reach court. Expected litigation outcomes influence behavior before any dispute arises.

In the running example, consider the buyer's decision ex ante.

If the buyer pays immediately, the cost is 100.

If the buyer withholds payment and the supplier sues, the buyer expects to settle at 92.

Even if every supplier sues, withholding is cheaper than paying immediately. Deterrence is therefore weak.

Deterrence becomes even weaker if not all suppliers sue.

Suppose only 40% of suppliers bring a lawsuit, due to fear of costs, delay, or liquidity constraints. Then the buyer's expected cost of withholding is:

  • 0.4 × 92 = 36.8

In that case, withholding payment is clearly preferable to paying 100.

This illustrates a central lesson of law and economics:

Legal rules do not deter harmful behavior unless they are enforced with sufficient probability and at sufficient cost.

Delay, Impatience, and Repeat Players

Delay plays a crucial role in litigation and settlement. If trial takes a long time, a cash-constrained supplier may prefer a lower settlement today to a higher expected value later.

Anticipating this, a well-capitalized buyer can use delay strategically to weaken the supplier's bargaining position. This advantage is especially pronounced for repeat players who are involved in many similar disputes.

As a result, even strong legal claims may settle for low amounts when one party is impatient or faces liquidity constraints.

Litigation as Part of an Enforcement System

Litigation should be understood as one element in a broader enforcement system that also includes private ordering, reputational sanctions, and public enforcement.

When private enforcement is weak, settlement outcomes may fail to deter opportunistic behavior. In such settings, stronger procedural rules, collective actions, or public enforcement may be required to restore deterrence.

The purpose of civil procedure is therefore not to maximize the number of lawsuits, but to make enforcement sufficiently credible to influence behavior ex ante.

General Lessons

The running example illustrates several general insights:

  • Lawsuits occur when expected trial payoffs exceed available alternatives.
  • Settlement is the normal outcome of costly and risky adjudication.
  • Settlement reflects bargaining power, not just legal rights.
  • Procedural rules affect behavior by shaping outside options.
  • Weak enforcement undermines deterrence, even when the law is clear.
  • Delay and asymmetries between parties play a central role in practice.

Summary and Exam-Relevant Takeaways

Students should be able to:

  • compute expected trial payoffs from probabilities, damages, and legal costs
  • derive a settlement range
  • explain how settlement outcomes arise from bargaining
  • analyze how procedural rules affect bargaining power
  • explain why the threat of litigation may fail to deter opportunism

Exam Questions

▶ Question 29: Carbon Capture Litigation Settlement

The cement company NordCem AS plans to install a carbon capture system at its plant in southern Norway to meet increasingly strict emission targets. NordCem has signed a letter of intent with CleanCarbon Technologies AS, a Norwegian technology company specializing in CO2 capture solutions for industrial applications.

The system promises to capture around 400,000 tonnes of CO2 per year—roughly 50% of NordCem's current emissions—using an amine-based chemical process. However, the actual capture rate depends on local operating conditions, such as kiln gas composition, temperature stability, and maintenance routines. If capture rates fall below expectations, NordCem risks exceeding its permitted emissions limits and will be required to purchase additional CO2 quotas under the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), potentially at a high market price.

CleanCarbon Technologies has delayed the delivery of the carbon capture system that NordCem AS ordered. As a result, NordCem has been forced to pay for additional CO2 quotas to cover emissions that would have been captured if the system had been operational on time. CleanCarbon refuses to compensate NordCem for these costs, and NordCem is considering filing a lawsuit. However, going to court would be expensive and could take a long time to resolve.

Which factors determine whether NordCem AS will file a lawsuit, whether the case will settle or proceed to court, and the likely size of any settlement? Discuss using economic theory.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Legal Incentives Model. Good answers could also draw on Cost–Benefit Analysis. The key is to identify NordCem’s decision margin (sue, settle, or drop) and show how it depends on expected recovery (the CO2 quota costs attributable to delay), the probability of prevailing, and the private costs of litigation and delay. A strong answer explains why settlement is often jointly preferred even when suing is privately profitable, by comparing each party’s expected payoff from trial to its payoff from agreement. It also highlights why cases nonetheless reach court when beliefs about winning diverge, or when bargaining breaks down due to private information about litigation costs, patience, or willingness to accept risk.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Legal Incentives Model, applying expected-value reasoning to the decisions to sue and to settle.

Actors and decision margin NordCem chooses whether to file suit against CleanCarbon (or instead threaten suit to induce payment), and then whether to accept a settlement or proceed to trial. CleanCarbon chooses whether to offer a settlement and on what terms, or to resist and litigate.

Incentives and behavioral responses NordCem’s incentive to sue depends on whether the expected value of suing exceeds the cost of suing (relative to doing nothing). Under risk neutrality, a simple condition is: \[ \text{Probability of winning}\times \text{Damages awarded} \;>\; \text{Probability of losing}\times \text{Legal costs}. \] This implies NordCem is more likely to sue when (i) the probability of winning is higher (clearer proof of breach/causation and fewer legal uncertainties), (ii) expected damages are larger (here, higher or longer-lasting EU ETS quota expenditures attributable to the delay), and (iii) legal costs are lower (lawyers, court fees, management time). Delay also matters: if trial takes a long time, the practical value of a later payment is lower, weakening the incentive to sue unless damages are correspondingly large.

Bargaining and settlement Even when suing has positive expected value for NordCem, both parties may prefer settlement because trial destroys surplus through litigation costs and time. A settlement is likely when there is a payment that makes NordCem at least as well off as going to court, while costing CleanCarbon no more than going to court.

Using the numerical illustration from the prompt: suppose NordCem’s extra quota costs are 20 million NOK, legal costs are 5 million NOK, and the probability NordCem wins is 70%.

  • NordCem’s expected value from trial is \(0.7\times 20 - 0.3\times 5 = 12.5\) million NOK.
  • CleanCarbon’s expected cost of trial is \(0.7\times 20 + 0.7\times 5 = 17.5\) million NOK.

There is therefore a settlement range from 12.5 to 17.5 million NOK where both parties prefer settling over court. Using Nash bargaining logic, a focal settlement is around the midpoint: \[ (12.5 + 17.5)/2 = 15 \text{ million NOK}. \]

The case may still go to court if (1) both sides are overly optimistic about their chances of winning (so the perceived settlement range disappears), or (2) bargaining fails due to asymmetric information (for example, one side privately knows its true litigation cost, patience, or risk tolerance and holds out for too much).

Conditional conclusion NordCem is more likely to file suit (or credibly threaten it) when the expected recovery from proving delay-caused quota costs is high and litigation costs and delay are comparatively low. Conditional on credible litigation threats, settlement is the default prediction because it avoids real resource costs of trial; the likely settlement size rises with the probability NordCem wins, the size of recoverable quota costs, and (when the probability of NordCem winning is above 50%) higher legal costs that make trial especially unattractive. The parties are more likely to proceed to court when beliefs about winning differ sharply or when private information about costs, patience, risk preferences, or reputational concerns prevents agreement.

▶ Question 30: Fee Shifting Clauses

You advise Biotech Innovations Ltd., a pharmaceutical firm specializing in developing and manufacturing innovative drugs. They have just innovated a new drug, "BioCureX," a breakthrough treatment for a rare genetic disorder. The active pharmaceutical ingredient required for BioCureX is exclusively supplied by PharmaChem Co. Biotech Innovations is about to sign a long-term supply agreement with PharmaChem. But they are worried that PharmaChem might fail to consistently supply the amount of the ingredient necessary for large-scale production.

You want to include one of the following clauses in the contract:

  • Clause A: "In the event of any dispute arising from or relating to this contract, including any legal action or proceeding, the prevailing party shall be entitled to recover its reasonable attorneys' fees and court costs incurred in connection with such dispute."
  • Clause B: "Each party shall bear its own attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses incurred in connection with any dispute arising from or relating to this contract, including any legal action or proceeding."

Which of these two clauses would you recommend to Biotech Innovations? Explain why using economic theory.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Cost–Benefit Analysis. Good answers could also draw on Legal Incentives Model. The core is to explain how fee shifting changes the parties’ expected payoffs from litigating versus settling, and therefore how the clause reallocates bargaining power in any post-dispute negotiation. A strong answer connects that bargaining effect to PharmaChem’s ex ante performance incentives: making a lawsuit a more credible and more costly threat can reduce the risk of non-supply. The answer should also address that “stronger deterrence” is not automatically efficient, because the clause can create excessive expected sanctions (and thus inefficient performance) and can increase real litigation activity even when the underlying merits are unchanged.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Cost–Benefit Analysis, together with the Legal Incentives Model.

Object and counterfactual The object is the choice between two dispute-resolution cost-allocation rules in a long-term supply contract: Clause A (prevailing-party attorneys’ fees and court costs) versus Clause B (each party bears its own fees). The counterfactual is signing the contract with the other clause, holding all other terms (price, quantity, damages for non-supply) fixed.

Incentives and behavioral responses Fee shifting changes the expected “sanction” from ending up in court. Under Clause A, a party that expects to lose not only anticipates paying the underlying amount owed (e.g., damages for non-supply), but also anticipates paying the other side’s reasonable litigation costs. Under Clause B, each side expects to pay its own litigation costs regardless of outcome, which reduces the expected additional cost of being the losing party.

A simple illustration: suppose a dispute is worth 100 (damages or the amount at stake), each side would spend 30 on litigation, and Biotech’s probability of winning is \(p=0.6\). Under Clause B, Biotech’s expected value of suing is roughly \(0.6\cdot 100 - 30 = 30\). Under Clause A, if Biotech wins it recovers its 30, and if it loses it pays PharmaChem’s 30; expected value is roughly \(0.6\cdot 100 - (1-0.6)\cdot 30 = 48\). So Clause A makes litigation a more attractive and therefore more credible threat for the side that is more likely to prevail. This matters here because Biotech’s concern is under-supply: if PharmaChem anticipates that breach will be met with a credible and costly legal response, it has stronger incentives to take costly steps to avoid breach (capacity, inventories, redundancy in sourcing inputs, better planning).

Bargaining and settlement Because most disputes settle “in the shadow of litigation,” the clause affects the settlement range and bargaining power. Under Clause A, if Biotech is more likely than not to win (as in the \(p>0.5\) case), its expected value from going to court increases, and PharmaChem’s expected cost from going to court increases. In Nash bargaining terms, Biotech’s outside option improves and PharmaChem’s outside option worsens, so the negotiated settlement shifts in Biotech’s favor.

Clause B weakens that shift. In particular, when the amount owed is relatively small but litigation is expensive, Biotech’s threat to sue can become non-credible under Clause B (the expected net recovery can be negative once Biotech must pay its own fees). Clause A can restore credibility in exactly those cases by letting the likely winner expect to recoup fees.

Real costs and benefits

  • Expected supply disruption / expected harm: If Clause A raises PharmaChem’s incentive to avoid breach, it can reduce the probability and duration of non-supply, lowering real disruption costs (idle capacity at Biotech, delayed treatment availability, costly rescheduling and revalidation).
  • Precaution / compliance costs by PharmaChem: Stronger enforcement pressure can increase real resource use to ensure performance (extra inventories, overtime, backup capacity). This is a benefit if it prevents higher expected disruption costs, but a cost if it induces excessive precautions relative to the value of performance.
  • Litigation and dispute-resolution costs: Clause A can reduce trials if it pushes parties to settle (because the expected loss from litigating is higher for the likely loser). But it can also increase the incentive to file suit in the first place when a party believes it is likely to win and recover fees, potentially increasing total legal spending. Clause B may reduce filing incentives but can also lead to more inefficient bargaining breakdowns when meritorious claims are not worth pursuing.
  • Inefficient performance (foregone efficient non-performance): If Clause A effectively makes the expected sanction too large, PharmaChem may “over-perform” and supply even in states where non-supply (paired with compensation) would be Kaldor–Hicks efficient (e.g., when supplying requires extremely costly emergency measures that exceed the value of avoiding disruption).

Attorneys’ fees payments themselves are transfers between the parties, not real resource costs; the real cost is the underlying legal work and court time.

A key ambiguity for efficiency is whether Clause A primarily (a) improves compliance and lowers expected disruption with limited extra legal spending, or (b) creates excessive expected sanctions and/or more legal spending without commensurate performance gains.

Conditional conclusion If Biotech’s main objective is reliable supply and it expects that (when disputes arise) it will usually have strong, documentable claims (so \(p\) is plausibly above 0.5), I would recommend Clause A because it strengthens Biotech’s litigation threat, improves its settlement position, and increases PharmaChem’s incentive not to breach. However, this recommendation is conditional on the overall expected sanction not becoming too large: if damages for non-supply are already high (or hard to calibrate) and performance can be extremely costly in some contingencies, adding fee shifting can create over-deterrence and inefficient performance; in that case Clause B may be better. The efficiency ranking therefore depends importantly on the underlying damages baseline (as in Question 1) and on how often and how cleanly non-supply can be proven in a dispute.

▶ Question 31: Lawyer Selection Contracts

You advise Biotech Innovations Ltd., a pharmaceutical firm specializing in developing and manufacturing innovative drugs. They have just innovated a new drug, "BioCureX," a breakthrough treatment for a rare genetic disorder. The active pharmaceutical ingredient required for BioCureX is exclusively supplied by PharmaChem Co. Biotech Innovations is about to sign a long-term supply agreement with PharmaChem. But they are worried that PharmaChem might fail to consistently supply the amount of the ingredient necessary for large-scale production.

Both sides sign the contract. After a while, it turns out PharmaChem has been supplying the wrong quality of the ingredient, making the drug ineffective. Biotech Innovations claims PharmaChem has violated the terms of the contract and threatens to sue for damages.

You are tasked to find a lawyer to represent Biotech Innovations in a legal dispute with PharmaChem. Which lawyer would you recommend to use? On which contractual terms would you recommend the lawyer to be engaged? Explain using economic theory.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Moral hazard. Good answers could also draw on Self-enforcement. The key is to identify Biotech Innovations as a principal buying an expert service whose quality (legal effort, strategy, and advice) is hard to observe and even harder to verify, creating scope for inefficiently high billed hours or inefficiently low effort depending on the payment scheme. Strong answers connect lawyer selection (reputation, repeat relationship, in-house counsel) to how future business and reputational losses can discipline behavior when courts cannot. They also compare hourly billing and contingency (or mixed) fees by explaining how each shifts incentives over effort, settlement posture, and case selection, and why the best choice depends on case stakes, expected recovery, and the firm’s ability to monitor.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Moral hazard and Self-enforcement.

Object and counterfactual Biotech Innovations must choose (i) which lawyer to hire and (ii) the compensation terms for that lawyer, for a dispute against PharmaChem about wrong-quality inputs. The counterfactual is hiring a “generic” outside lawyer on standard hourly terms without reputational or relational constraints, which risks poor alignment between Biotech’s interests and the lawyer’s incentives.

Incentives and behavioral responses The core problem is agency in expert services. Biotech (principal) wants high-quality litigation and settlement advice at low real cost; the lawyer (agent) chooses effort, staffing, research intensity, and settlement posture. Much of this is not directly observable or verifiable, so the lawyer can (a) overprovide low-value hours or (b) underprovide effort, depending on the fee scheme.

This motivates recommending one of the following lawyer types:

  • A reputable specialist firm/lawyer in supply/quality disputes (and ideally pharma-regulated inputs): reputation is a valuable asset. If the lawyer performs poorly or opportunistically (e.g., padding hours, sloppy work), future clients may avoid them. That prospective loss disciplines behavior today.
  • A lawyer with whom Biotech has a long-term relationship (relational contracting): the “shadow of the future” works similarly. The lawyer internalizes that opportunism today risks losing repeated future mandates (and possibly referrals).
  • An in-house lawyer (or in-house led with targeted external support): an employee relationship can make monitoring easier (daily interaction, internal reporting lines) and can reduce incentives to run up hours, though it may be weaker for highly specialized litigation tasks unless complemented with outside counsel.

Contract terms should be chosen to align effort and settlement incentives:

  • Hourly billing makes the lawyer’s private benefit increase with billed time. This can induce too many hours, inefficient staffing, and advice that favors prolonged litigation over efficient settlement (because more time can mean more fees).
  • Contingency / “success” compensation (a higher payment if Biotech obtains a strong result) makes the lawyer internalize the value of winning/settling well. But because additional effort is costly to the lawyer and payment is tied to outcome, the lawyer may spend too few hours (especially on hard margin tasks) and may be too eager to settle early to lock in compensation and avoid further effort.

A simple illustration: suppose an additional 40 hours of expert work would increase Biotech’s expected recovery by 100 (in expected-value terms). Under hourly billing at 3 per hour, the lawyer is paid 120 for those hours even if the work only adds 100 in expected value, so the lawyer’s incentive can be to do “too much” relative to Biotech’s interest. Under a 20% contingency fee, the lawyer’s upside from that extra 100 is only 20, so the lawyer may rationally do “too little” even when it is efficient for Biotech.

Given the facts (a specialized, high-stakes input-quality dispute where quality and strategy are hard to evaluate), a mixed fee is often best within this toolkit: a moderate hourly component (ensuring adequate resourcing) combined with a clearly defined success component (aligning incentives toward value rather than hours). If Biotech is liquidity-constrained or cannot monitor at all, shifting more weight toward success pay can be attractive; if Biotech can monitor and the case requires extensive verifiable work, more hourly pay can be justified.

Real costs and benefits

  • Litigation effort costs (real lawyer time and support resources): hourly billing tends to increase total hours and staffing relative to the counterfactual; a pure contingency fee tends to reduce hours and may reduce necessary investment in case development.
  • Monitoring and internal administration costs: hourly billing typically increases the need for auditing bills, supervising tasks, and disputing invoices; repeat relationships, in-house counsel, and reputational constraints can reduce these monitoring needs.
  • Expected outcome quality (probability of winning / favorable settlement): hiring a reputable specialist and using incentives that reward success can increase expected recovery by inducing higher-value effort and better strategic choices.
  • Delay and distraction costs: excessive hours and aggressive litigation posture can increase case duration, tying up management attention and slowing operational decisions (e.g., replacement sourcing, production planning).
  • Risk of distorted settlement decisions: hourly billing can bias advice against settlement (prolonging the dispute); contingency fees can bias advice toward premature settlement, especially if marginal effort is costly and outcome uncertainty is high.

Attorney’s fees, damages paid, and contingency shares are largely transfers between Biotech and the lawyer (and possibly between Biotech and PharmaChem) and therefore are not counted as real resource costs; they matter here because they change incentives and behavior.

Verifiability and enforcement Biotech can verify some inputs (time sheets, filings, attendance), but cannot reliably verify the quality of legal judgment, negotiation posture, or whether an extra hour was truly high value. Because quality is hard for a court to police ex post, Biotech must rely on incentive-compatible pay and private disciplining devices: reputation, repeat business, and internal supervision (in-house counsel overseeing outside counsel). Outcome-contingent pay uses an observable proxy (case result) for effort, but the proxy is noisy and can push the lawyer toward “quick and sure” outcomes rather than maximal expected value.

Conditional conclusion If Biotech expects this dispute (and similar ones) to be high-stakes and hard to monitor, it should hire a reputable specialist (or a lawyer with a repeat relationship, or in-house-led counsel) and rely on self-enforcement through reputation/relationship value to mitigate agency problems. On terms, a hybrid (some hourly plus a success component) is preferred when (i) the case requires substantial hard-to-specify effort and (ii) Biotech wants to avoid both hour-padding and underinvestment. If Biotech can monitor closely and needs intensive verifiable work, leaning more toward hourly terms is stronger; if monitoring is weak or liquidity is tight, leaning more toward success-based pay becomes more attractive, accepting the risk of too-early settlement.

▶ Question 32: American Rule Performance Incentives

A start-up tech company develops AI-powered apps for its customers. Since the company is low on cash, it prefers to receive half the payment before it starts developing the app. The remaining half of the payment is paid when the company delivers the app to the customer.

Assume the company wants to expand to the United States. There, each party to a lawsuit pays its own legal fees irrespective of the outcome of the case. How does this change in the legal environment affect the company's incentives to keep its promises? Which factors does your answer depend on? Explain using economic theory.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Legal Incentives Model. It typically identifies the firm’s relevant choice as “perform (develop and deliver) versus breach and face a dispute,” and then explains how the American Rule changes the expected sanction by changing each side’s expected litigation costs and the credibility of the customer’s threat to sue. Strong answers connect this to settlement through bargaining: when the customer must pay its own legal fees even if it wins, suing becomes less attractive, the firm’s outside option improves, and the expected settlement payment falls, weakening performance incentives. The conclusion depends on the probability the customer would win, expected damages (tied to the customer’s valuation), litigation costs, and how close the development cost is to the value at stake.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use the Legal Incentives Model, focusing on how fee-shifting affects the customer’s threat to sue and therefore the firm’s expected cost of breach (including through settlement).

Object and counterfactual The object is the move from a “loser pays” rule (as in Norway) to the American Rule (each party pays its own legal fees regardless of outcome) for disputes about non-delivery after the customer has paid half up front. The counterfactual is the original environment where the loser typically pays the other side’s legal fees.

Actors and decision margin

  • Company: decides whether to keep its promise by developing and delivering the app, or to breach (e.g., not deliver) after receiving the upfront payment.
  • Customer: if the company breaches, decides whether to sue (or credibly threaten suit) and on what terms to settle.

The key margin is whether the company finds it privately cheaper to perform or to breach and then pay an expected sanction (often via settlement).

Incentives and behavioral responses Under the Legal Incentives Model, breach is attractive when the firm’s private benefit from breach (here: saving the development cost) exceeds the expected sanction. The expected sanction is shaped not only by damages, but also by the probability of the customer prevailing and by the parties’ litigation costs under the fee rule.

Assume:

  • Total litigation cost is 20.
  • Norway: loser pays 20.
  • United States: each party pays 10 regardless of outcome.
  • If the company has not kept its promise, the customer wins with probability \(p = 0.9\).
  • If the customer wins, the judge awards expectation damages equal to the customer’s valuation (first example: 120).
  • The parties settle (no asymmetric information) via Nash bargaining, so the settlement splits the surplus relative to trial.

Compute expected trial values and implied settlement:

  Norway United States
Legal fees 20 paid by loser 10 paid by each
Value of lawsuit for customer \(0.9 \times 120 - 0.1 \times 20 = 106\) \(0.9 \times 120 - 10 = 98\)
Cost of lawsuit for company \(0.9 \times 120 + 0.9 \times 20 = 126\) \(0.9 \times 120 + 10 = 118\)
Settlement (Nash bargaining) \((106+126)/2 = 116\) \((98+118)/2 = 108\)

Economic mechanism: under the American Rule, suing becomes less attractive for the customer (it must pay 10 even when it wins), and breach becomes less costly for the company (it no longer risks paying the customer’s fees when it loses). This improves the company’s bargaining position and lowers the settlement amount (here, from 116 to 108). That reduced settlement is a reduced expected sanction for breach, so it weakens performance incentives relative to “loser pays.”

In this numerical example, the company still performs if developing costs 80, because it is cheaper to develop (cost 80) than to breach and settle (pay 108).

But the tendency is that the American Rule makes breach more attractive, and for other numbers it can flip the performance decision. For instance, if the customer’s valuation is 105 and the cost of developing is 95 (keeping the same \(p=0.9\) and total litigation cost 20 split as 10/10 in the US):

  Norway United States
Legal fees 20 paid by loser 10 paid by each
Value of lawsuit for customer \(0.9 \times 105 - 0.1 \times 20 = 92.5\) \(0.9 \times 105 - 10 = 84.5\)
Cost of lawsuit for company \(0.9 \times 105 + 0.9 \times 20 = 112.5\) \(0.9 \times 105 + 10 = 104.5\)
Settlement (Nash bargaining) \((92.5+112.5)/2 = 102.5\) \((84.5+104.5)/2 = 94.5\)

Here, under the American Rule the expected settlement is 94.5, which is below the development cost 95, so the company would prefer to breach and settle rather than develop. In that sense, the company “cannot be trusted” to develop apps where the customer’s valuation (and thus damages) is not much above the development cost.

Finally, if litigation costs are very high relative to the disputed amount, the customer may not have incentives to sue at all, making the threat of suit not credible. For example:

  • If the customer’s valuation is 120 but the customer would have to pay 1000 in its own legal costs, then suing yields \(0.9 \times 120 - 1000 = -892\).
  • Even with moderate legal fees, a low-value app can make suing unattractive: if the value is 10 and the customer must pay 10 in fees under the American Rule, then \(0.9 \times 10 - 10 = -1\).

If the customer will not sue, the expected sanction is effectively near zero and the contract provides little legal incentive for delivery.

Real costs and benefits

  • App development (performance) costs: Performing requires real resource costs (e.g., 80 or 95 in the examples). A weaker expected sanction for breach increases the likelihood these costs are avoided via breach (but at the expense of losing the app’s value).
  • Litigation and adjudication costs: Trial uses real resources (e.g., total cost 20, or in the extreme example 1000). Rules that change who bears these costs affect the frequency of suits and the likelihood of settlement versus trial.
  • Expected loss of valuable projects (misallocation): If weaker enforcement makes breach more attractive in “close cases” (valuation only slightly above development cost), some trades that would be efficient to perform may instead end in non-delivery and dispute.

Note: damages/settlement payments are transfers between the parties, not real resource costs. They matter here because they determine incentives and bargaining positions.

Bargaining and settlement With symmetric information, the credible threat point is each side’s expected value from going to trial. Under the American Rule, the customer’s trial value falls (it must pay its own fees even when it wins), and the firm’s expected trial cost falls (it no longer expects to pay the customer’s fees when it loses). This shifts the Nash bargaining outcome toward a lower settlement payment. A lower expected settlement reduces the firm’s expected sanction for breach and therefore weakens incentives to keep promises, especially when the project’s surplus is small.

Conditional conclusion Moving from “loser pays” to the American Rule tends to reduce the company’s incentives to keep its promises, because it reduces the customer’s incentive (and sometimes ability) to sue and lowers the settlement the customer can credibly demand. The effect is strongest when (i) litigation costs are high, (ii) the app’s value (and thus expectation damages) is small, and (iii) the customer’s valuation is not much higher than the cost of developing the app (so a modest reduction in expected settlement can make breach privately optimal). If, instead, valuation and expected damages are far above development cost and litigation costs are modest, the company may still have strong incentives to perform even under the American Rule.

▶ Question 33: Insurance Fraud Settlement

Selskapet TryggBolig AS tilbyr innboforsikring til privatpersoner. De siste årene har flere kunder valgt å stå uten forsikring, samtidig som antallet store skadeutbetalinger har økt. Bransjen rapporterer også om økende forekomst av forsikringssvindel, særlig ved påståtte tyverier og brannskader. Enkelte kunder har fått avslag fordi selskapet mener skadene ikke er tilstrekkelig dokumentert.

Etter flere tilfeller av mistenkt forsikringssvindel vurderer TryggBolig AS hvordan de bør håndtere tvister med kunder som får avslag på erstatning. I ett tilfelle hevder en kunde at en brann ødela innboet, men selskapet mener brannen var påsatt og har avslått utbetaling. Kunden varsler søksmål. Selskapet kan enten inngå forlik for å unngå rettssak, eller nekte utbetaling og risikere søksmål. Diskuter hvilken strategi TryggBolig AS bør velge ved hjelp av økonomisk teori.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Legal Incentives Model. Good answers could also draw on Moral hazard. The core content identifies TryggBolig AS’s choice between settling and litigating as a trade-off between short-run dispute costs (legal fees, delay, managerial time, and the risk of an adverse judgment) and long-run incentive effects on fraudulent and borderline claims. Strong answers connect the firm’s stance in one case to how future customers update their expectations about the probability of non-payment and sanctions, and therefore to the incidence of arson/false theft claims and the quality of the insured pool. The analysis should be sensitive to verifiability: when arson is hard to prove in court, litigation may be expensive with limited deterrence, and an overly aggressive strategy can also drive away honest customers.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Legal Incentives Model and Moral hazard.

Object and counterfactual TryggBolig must choose a strategy in a dispute after denying a fire claim it suspects is arson: (i) settle to avoid trial, or (ii) refuse payment and accept the risk of litigation. The relevant counterfactual is how each strategy affects (a) the expected cost of this particular case and (b) incentives for future customers deciding whether to buy insurance and whether to submit honest, exaggerated, or fraudulent claims.

Incentives and behavioral responses The suspected problem is hidden action after contracting: customers may increase the likelihood or size of claims (including outright fraud). Under the Legal Incentives Model, a potential fraudster compares the private benefit from fraud \(B\) (getting the payout) to the expected sanction \(pS\), where \(p\) reflects the chance the fraud is detected/defeated (and potentially referred for further consequences) and \(S\) is what the customer loses if caught (non-payment, legal consequences, and other costs tied to being identified as fraudulent). A strategy of routinely settling disputed denials lowers \(p\) from the fraudster’s perspective and therefore increases the set of cases where \(B>pS\); that tends to increase fraud, inflate expected payouts over time, and can also worsen the insurance pool if honest customers exit when premiums rise. By contrast, a credible willingness to litigate suspected fraud increases \(p\) (and can increase effective \(S\) if the case is pursued seriously), which can deter fraudulent or weak claims and reduce expected payouts in future periods.

Verifiability and enforcement Whether litigation is a good deterrent depends on what can be proven. Arson is often observable to investigators but hard to verify to a court with admissible evidence. If the firm cannot raise \(p\) (probability of prevailing on the denial / probability fraud is effectively sanctioned) without very high investigative and legal spending, then “litigate to deter” can become an expensive signal with limited effect. Conversely, if the company can document suspicious circumstances in a way that courts accept, litigation becomes a cheaper way to raise \(p\), and the expected deterrence effect is larger.

Bargaining and settlement The bargaining range is shaped by expected trial outcomes and litigation costs. If TryggBolig credibly commits to litigate strong fraud cases, it improves its outside option in negotiations in similar future disputes (claimants expect a higher chance of receiving nothing after denial), which tends to reduce the settlement amounts needed to avoid trial. If instead the company develops a reputation for “denial followed by settlement,” claimants—fraudulent and honest—expect payment after threatening suit, which raises the settlement demand and increases the number of contested claims. In other words, settlement is not only a one-shot cost-minimization choice; it also sets a precedent that changes the bargaining position in later disputes.

Real costs and benefits

  • Litigation and investigation costs: refusing payment can trigger lawyer time, expert reports, and internal resources; settling avoids much of this in the current case.
  • Expected harm from fraud (misallocation of resources): a soft settlement strategy increases fraudulent claiming and arson incentives, raising real resources wasted on destructive behavior and on generating fake evidence.
  • Error and deterrence costs for honest policyholders: aggressive denial-and-litigate policies can impose delay, stress, and additional documentation burdens on honest claimants; over time this can reduce efficient insurance take-up and push low-risk customers out.
  • Administrative costs of claims handling: a strategy that induces more disputes increases handling time and casework.

(Transfers such as paying a settlement or paying out under the policy are not real resource costs in a social cost–benefit sense, but they matter for TryggBolig’s private incentives and therefore for the behavioral effects described above.)

A simple numerical illustration clarifies the one-shot trade-off. Suppose the disputed payout is 200, litigation costs are 50, and the probability the court makes TryggBolig pay is \(p=0.30\). Then refusing payment and litigating has expected outlay \(50 + 0.30 \cdot 200 = 110\). If the customer offers to settle for 120, settlement looks cheaper in this case. But if litigating this case materially increases deterrence (by raising perceived \(p\) in future fraud attempts), the long-run benefit can justify litigating even when the one-shot expected outlay is slightly higher.

Conditional conclusion TryggBolig should refuse payment and be willing to litigate when (i) the evidentiary position is strong enough that \(p\) (probability the company must pay after trial) is low, and/or (ii) the deterrence value from raising perceived \(pS\) for would-be fraudsters is large (because fraud is prevalent and responsive to expected sanctions). TryggBolig should prefer settlement when verifiability is weak (high \(p\) despite being suspicious), litigation costs are high, or the reputational/retention cost from prolonged disputes with likely honest customers is large—since in those cases “litigate to deter” mostly buys expense rather than higher effective enforcement. A sensible strategy is therefore a differentiated one: settle marginal cases where proof is hard and the expected trial loss is high, but litigate (and publicize internally as a policy) clear fraud cases to maintain a credible threat and reduce future fraudulent claiming.

▶ Question 34: Consumer Class Actions

NordEnergi AS er en mellomstor strømleverandør som selger kraft til både husholdninger og bedrifter. I 2024 opplevde selskapet store svingninger i strømprisene som følge av økt eksport, varierende tilsig til vannmagasinene og uforutsigbare værforhold. Flere kunder og industribedrifter mener prisene har vært urimelig høye, og det har oppstått en debatt om hvorvidt dagens markedsmodell for strøm fungerer etter hensikten.

Forbrukerrådet vurderer å gå til søksmål mot NordEnergi for villedende markedsføring av strømavtaler. Diskuter ved hjelp av økonomisk teori hvorfor Forbrukerrådet burde kunne saksøke på vegne av forbrukerne, i stedet for at hver enkelt kunde må gå til sak selv.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Cost–Benefit Analysis. Good answers could also draw on the Legal Incentives Model. The key content is why dispersed consumer claims tend to be under-enforced when each customer must sue alone: each victim’s expected recovery is small relative to the fixed costs of finding counsel, collecting evidence, and bearing litigation risk, so the probability of a lawsuit becomes low even if the underlying conduct is widespread. A strong answer connects representative litigation to deterrence by showing how aggregating many small harms raises the expected sanction \(pS\) facing the firm and thus reduces incentives for misleading marketing. It also identifies the main welfare trade-offs: lower duplication and better information production versus the risk of weak screening or excessive settlement pressure.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Cost–Benefit Analysis, and the Legal Incentives Model.

Object and counterfactual The institutional choice is whether the Consumer Council (Forbrukerrådet) should be allowed to sue NordEnergi on behalf of many consumers for misleading marketing of electricity contracts (a representative/class action-type mechanism). The counterfactual is that each individual customer must decide whether to bring (and finance) an individual claim.

Incentives and behavioral responses If each consumer must sue alone, enforcement is likely to be weak because each consumer’s loss is typically small compared to the fixed costs of bringing a case (lawyer time, evidence collection, time cost, and litigation risk). That makes it privately rational not to sue even when the marketing was misleading and harmed many consumers. The predictable behavioral response is “no one sues,” so firms face a low probability of being sanctioned.

Under the Legal Incentives Model, NordEnergi’s incentive to engage in misleading marketing depends on whether the private benefit \(B\) from doing so exceeds the expected sanction \(pS\). Requiring individual lawsuits tends to keep \(p\) low (few suits are filed) and \(S\) low in practice (each case is small), which weakens deterrence. Allowing the Consumer Council to sue on behalf of all affected consumers increases \(p\) (a single actor can credibly bring the case) and effectively increases \(S\) (aggregated harm makes liability meaningful), which moves behavior toward less misleading marketing.

A simple illustration: suppose each consumer’s expected loss from misleading marketing is 200, but filing an individual case effectively costs 50,000 in time and legal expenses. Even a fully meritorious claim will not be brought, so \(p\) is near zero. If 10,000 consumers are affected, the total harm is 2,000,000; one representative case might cost 200,000 to litigate, making enforcement feasible and making \(pS\) large enough to deter.

Verifiability and enforcement Misleading marketing often turns on verifiable evidence such as standardized advertising claims, contract terms, screenshots, and internal documents about how products were presented. A representative plaintiff can invest in producing and organizing such evidence once, instead of duplicating that investment across many cases. At the same time, some issues may be harder to verify at the group level (e.g., what each consumer understood, or individualized reliance), which can limit how much of the harm can be proven and therefore limit \(S\). The institutional advantage of a representative plaintiff is precisely that it can focus resources on what is verifiable and enforceable, raising effective enforcement where individual consumers would not.

Bargaining and settlement A single representative plaintiff changes bargaining leverage. With dispersed individual suits, NordEnergi can often “wait out” consumers because each consumer’s outside option is weak (not suing is cheap and common), so credible litigation threats are rare and settlements—if any—will not reflect the full social harm. A representative suit concentrates the claim and creates a credible threat of adjudication, which tends to move settlements toward reflecting the aggregate expected liability. This can improve deterrence, but it also creates a risk that a very large aggregated claim generates strong pressure to settle even when the merits are mixed; the welfare comparison therefore depends on screening and governance of the representative action.

Real costs and benefits

  • Litigation and adjudication costs: A representative action reduces duplicated fixed costs (many separate filings, repeated legal work) relative to thousands of individual claims, but it can increase the complexity of the single case (class definition, notice, aggregate proof).
  • Information production and error costs: Centralized litigation can improve evidence production and legal clarity (one well-developed record), reducing the risk of inconsistent judgments; however, aggregation can also raise the cost of tailoring proof to individual circumstances, potentially increasing adjudication error for individualized elements.
  • Expected harm from misleading marketing: Better enforcement reduces misleading marketing and thus reduces inefficient consumer choices (consumers selecting contracts on the wrong terms) and the real resource costs that follow (time spent switching, searching, disputing bills, and inefficient consumption decisions driven by distorted price signals).
  • Compliance and precaution costs for firms: Stronger enforcement increases firms’ incentives to invest in clearer marketing, better disclosure, and internal compliance systems; these are real costs, but they are also the channel through which harm is prevented.

Any damages, fines, or settlement payments are transfers and are not counted as real resource costs or benefits; they matter because they shape \(pS\) and thus behavior.

Overall, representative litigation is most likely to raise welfare when individual claims are small and numerous (so individual enforcement collapses), the misleading practice is fairly standardized (so common proof is feasible), and the representative plaintiff provides good screening so the system does not spend resources on weak cases.

Conditional conclusion Allowing the Consumer Council to sue on behalf of consumers is economically justified if (i) individual consumers’ incentives to sue are too weak to generate meaningful enforcement, so \(p\) is otherwise very low, and (ii) the case involves common, verifiable conduct so that one lawsuit can efficiently produce evidence and deter future misleading marketing. If instead harms are highly individualized and difficult to verify in aggregate, or if representative litigation is poorly screened (raising litigation and error costs), then the cost side can dominate and the case for representative standing is weaker.

▶ Question 35: Patent Troll Credible Threat

A Norwegian technology firm, TechNor AS, has achieved great success in its domestic market and has recently decided to expand its operations to the United States. The company has launched a new product line in the U.S. market, but shortly after entering the market it receives a notice of lawsuit from an American company, IP Holdings, which is known to be a patent troll. IP Holdings claims that TechNor has infringed its patent on a technology that is only marginally related to TechNor’s products. The notice of lawsuit includes a demand that TechNor must pay a large licensing fee to continue selling its products in the United States; otherwise, IP Holdings will proceed to litigation. TechNor considers it likely that it would prevail in such litigation, but is concerned about the costs that a lawsuit would impose on the company (in the United States, each party pays its own legal costs regardless of who wins the case).

TechNor believes that the threat of litigation is not credible and is considering ignoring the notice of legal action. Under what assumptions are they correct? Discuss using economic theory.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Legal Incentives Model. Good answers could also draw on Self-enforcement to capture reputation-based incentives for carrying out threats. The central issue is whether IP Holdings’ threat to sue is a credible threat, which turns on IP Holdings’ expected private payoff from litigation under the U.S. “each side pays its own legal costs” rule. Strong answers make clear that TechNor’s belief that it would likely win is relevant but not decisive: even a low win probability can still support a credible threat if the upside from winning is large and IP Holdings’ litigation costs are low. Good answers also explain when publicity and repeat-play can make IP Holdings sue even when a one-shot expected-value calculation would be negative.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Legal Incentives Model and Self-enforcement.

Actors and decision margin TechNor chooses whether to ignore the demand (and thereby risk litigation) or to pay a license fee/settle. IP Holdings chooses whether to file suit if TechNor refuses. The question is when IP Holdings’ “we will sue” statement is a credible threat—i.e., when suing is in IP Holdings’ interest once refusal occurs.

Incentives and behavioral responses Ignoring the notice is rational for TechNor if, conditional on refusing to pay, IP Holdings would not actually sue. Without reputation effects, credibility is an expected-value question for IP Holdings: it will sue if the expected upside from winning exceeds its own expected litigation costs (since under the U.S. rule it bears its own costs whether it wins or loses).

Let \(p\) be the probability IP Holdings wins in court, and let \(B\) be the monetary value to IP Holdings of winning (license fee imposed by judgment and/or damages). Then the threat is credible when: \[ pB \;>\; \text{IP Holdings’ litigation costs.} \] This makes the threat more credible when: (i) \(p\) is higher (IP Holdings has a stronger patent claim or litigation advantage), (ii) \(B\) is higher (large damages/royalty exposure), and (iii) IP Holdings’ litigation costs are lower (specialization, scale, or low marginal cost of suing). TechNor’s assessment that it is “likely to win” means \(p\) is low, but the threat can still be credible if \(B\) is very large or IP Holdings’ costs are very small.

A simple illustration: if \(p=0.2\) and winning is worth \(B=10\) (in arbitrary units), then \(pB=2\). If IP Holdings’ own litigation costs are 3, suing is privately unprofitable and the threat is not credible in a one-shot setting; if its costs are 1, the threat is credible even though TechNor is likely to win.

Bargaining and settlement Because TechNor expects to bear significant legal costs even if it wins, TechNor may rationally pay a settlement/lump-sum license to avoid those costs. This is exactly what makes the “patent troll” strategy profitable: the defendant’s private cost of defense creates settlement leverage for the plaintiff. But this leverage does not by itself make the threat credible; it only matters if IP Holdings would in fact sue when challenged.

Verifiability and enforcement The key enforcement feature here is the U.S. cost rule: IP Holdings cannot rely on fee shifting to recover its own legal costs if it wins, which tends to reduce the credibility of marginal cases (it raises the effective “cost of enforcement” of the threat). Conversely, if IP Holdings can keep its own litigation costs low (e.g., through experience or arrangements that reduce its out-of-pocket expenses), the expected-cost side falls and credibility increases.

Incentives and behavioral responses With reputation effects, credibility can increase. If IP Holdings repeatedly targets new firms, it may value having a reputation for “following through” against firms that ignore demand letters. Then IP Holdings may sue even when the one-shot calculation \(pB\) minus litigation costs is negative, because not suing would weaken future threats and reduce future settlements. These reputation incentives require that relevant audiences can observe whether IP Holdings carries out threats; therefore, they are most plausible when the demand and the subsequent response are (or become) public.

Conditional conclusion TechNor is right that the threat is not credible if (1) in a one-shot setting IP Holdings’ expected gain from suing is negative—i.e., \(p\) is low and/or the win payoff is modest and/or IP Holdings’ litigation costs are high under the U.S. rule—and (2) there is no effective reputation mechanism (for example, because the threat and refusal are not public, or because IP Holdings already has a reputation for not following through). If instead IP Holdings’ expected-value case is positive, or if the situation is public and IP Holdings is a repeat player that benefits from maintaining a tough reputation, then ignoring the notice becomes risky because suing can be a credible response even when TechNor is likely to win on the merits.

▶ Question 36: Patent Troll Settlement

A Norwegian technology company, TechNor AS, has achieved great success in its domestic market and has recently decided to expand its operations to the United States. The company has launched a new product line in the U.S. market, but shortly after entry it receives a notice of lawsuit from an American company, IP Holdings, which is known to be a patent troll. IP Holdings alleges that TechNor has infringed its patent on a technology that is only marginally related to TechNor’s products. The notice of lawsuit includes a demand that TechNor must pay a substantial licensing fee in order to continue selling its products in the United States; otherwise, IP Holdings will proceed to litigation. TechNor considers it likely that it would prevail in such litigation, but is concerned about the costs that a lawsuit would impose on the company (in the United States, each party pays its own legal costs regardless of which party wins the case).

TechNor is alternatively considering entering into a settlement under which IP Holdings agrees to withdraw the lawsuit in exchange for a lump-sum payment. Which factors determine the magnitude of the payment that TechNor will likely be able to negotiate? Discuss using economic theory.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Legal Incentives Model. Good answers could also draw on Cost–Benefit Analysis. The core of the analysis identifies the parties’ outside options if no deal is reached, which here is litigation under the American rule (each side bears its own legal costs), and then explains how a negotiated lump-sum settlement will split the expected “surplus” from avoiding trial. The settlement amount should be tied to (i) the probability the patent troll wins, (ii) what the troll obtains if it wins (damages or a de facto license value), and (iii) each side’s litigation costs, because these determine each side’s willingness to pay/accept. Strong answers also recognize that repeated play and reputational concerns can shift bargaining power even when the legal merits are weak.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use the Legal Incentives Model, and Cost–Benefit Analysis.

Object and counterfactual The object is a negotiated settlement: IP Holdings drops the threatened lawsuit in exchange for a one-time payment from TechNor. The counterfactual is that no settlement is reached and the parties litigate in the US system described (each side pays its own litigation costs regardless of who wins).

Bargaining and settlement A useful way to pin down a likely settlement is to compute each party’s expected value of going to trial (their outside option) and then ask how the gains from avoiding trial are split in bargaining (often summarized by a “midpoint”/Nash-type split when bargaining power is symmetric).

Let \(p\) be the probability that IP Holdings wins at trial, and let \(S\) be what TechNor must pay if IP Holdings wins (damages and/or the effective value of the asserted license if liability is found).

  • IP Holdings’ expected value of litigation is the expected payoff from winning minus its own legal expenses: \[ pS - (\text{IP Holdings litigation costs}). \]
  • TechNor’s expected cost of litigation is the expected payment if it loses plus its own legal expenses: \[ pS + (\text{TechNor litigation costs}). \]

If the parties settle, they avoid both sides’ litigation costs. Relative to trial, settlement therefore creates a “surplus” equal to the sum of avoided litigation costs. A symmetric Nash-type bargaining solution splits that surplus equally. Written as a settlement payment from TechNor to IP Holdings, this gives: \[ \text{Settlement} \;=\; pS \;+\; \frac{(\text{TechNor litigation costs})-(\text{IP Holdings litigation costs})}{2}. \] This expression matches the intuition that the payment starts from the troll’s expected merits-based value \(pS\), and then is adjusted upward when TechNor saves more (or is more exposed) on litigation costs than IP Holdings.

Therefore, the factors that determine the size of the settlement TechNor can negotiate are:

  1. The probability \(p\) that IP Holdings wins (higher \(p\) increases the settlement).
  2. The amount \(S\) TechNor must pay if IP Holdings wins (higher \(S\) increases the settlement).
  3. TechNor’s litigation costs (higher costs increase the settlement because TechNor is willing to pay more to avoid trial).
  4. IP Holdings’ litigation costs (higher costs reduce the settlement because IP Holdings is more willing to accept less to avoid trial).

A simple illustration: suppose \(p=0.2\), \(S=\$10\) million, TechNor’s litigation costs are \(\$3\) million, and IP Holdings’ litigation costs are \(\$1\) million. Then \(pS=\$2\) million, and the midpoint adjustment is \((3-1)/2=\$1\) million, so the predicted settlement is about \(\$3\) million. Even though TechNor expects to win (low \(p\)), high litigation costs can still make a non-trivial settlement rational.

A very good answer also recognizes that reputation can shift the bargaining outcome. IP Holdings benefits from a reputation for “following through” on threats, because that increases future targets’ perceived \(p\) (or perceived \(S\)) and makes them settle quickly. Accepting a very small settlement—if it becomes known—can weaken that reputation and reduce future settlement leverage. Conversely, TechNor may value a reputation for not being an “easy target,” because paying quickly today can invite more threats tomorrow; that can make TechNor credibly willing to litigate even when settlement would be cheaper in a one-shot sense.

Conditional conclusion TechNor’s likely negotiated lump-sum payment is pinned down by the expected trial transfer \(pS\) and by the parties’ relative litigation costs under the American rule; higher \(p\), higher \(S\), and higher TechNor litigation costs push the settlement up, while higher IP Holdings litigation costs push it down. This conclusion is conditional on (i) bargaining power being roughly symmetric (so a midpoint/Nash-type split is a reasonable benchmark) and (ii) the reputational consequences being limited; if IP Holdings has substantially stronger bargaining power or larger reputational stakes, the settlement can be pushed above the midpoint, while if TechNor’s anti-troll reputation strategy is important, it can rationally hold out for a lower amount or litigate.

▶ Question 37: Patent Troll Norway vs USA

Patent trolls are less prevalent in Norway than in the United States. What might be the reason for this? Explain using economic theory. Hint: Two factors you may include in the discussion are that (i) in the United States the parties bear their own litigation costs, whereas the main rule in Norway is that the loser pays, and (ii) the requirements for patents are stricter in Norway.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Cost–Benefit Analysis and the Legal Incentives Model. It identifies the patent troll’s business model as extracting settlements by exploiting the target firm’s expected litigation burden, and then explains how fee-shifting rules change that expected burden even when the target expects to win on the merits. It also links stricter patentability requirements to a lower probability that the troll can credibly win, which weakens the troll’s threat point in settlement bargaining. The strongest answers connect these two institutional differences: lower expected costs for targets and higher expected costs for trolls reduce the equilibrium size and frequency of troll-driven settlements, making trolling less profitable and therefore less common.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Cost–Benefit Analysis and the Legal Incentives Model.

Object and counterfactual We compare two legal environments relevant for patent-troll activity: (i) a “each party pays its own legal costs” rule (as in the US baseline in the prompt) versus (ii) a “loser pays” rule (Norway’s main rule), and (iii) weaker versus stricter patentability requirements. The counterfactual is the same underlying technology firm facing the same type of demand letter, but under different expected litigation and validity conditions.

Incentives and behavioral responses A patent troll’s payoff comes mainly from settlements. The troll can obtain a settlement to the extent the targeted firm prefers paying now to facing expected litigation costs later.

Let \(p\) be the probability the target firm wins if the case goes to court. Then the target’s expected litigation cost can be written as: \[ p \times (\text{cost if the target wins}) + (1-p) \times (\text{cost if the target loses}). \] Under a loser-pays rule, the cost if the target wins is close to zero (the winner recovers legal costs). The expected cost is then mainly \((1-p)\times(\text{cost if the target loses})\). If, in addition, patentability requirements are stricter, it is harder for the troll to find “vague” patents that are sufficiently related to the target’s product to create a meaningful chance of winning. That raises \(p\) (the target is more likely to win), so \((1-p)\) becomes small. The target therefore has little reason to pay a large settlement “just to avoid court.”

In the US-style each-party-pays system, the target expects to bear substantial legal costs even if it wins on the merits. That means the “cost if the target wins” is not close to zero. As a result, the troll can credibly threaten to impose real litigation costs even with a weak case. In the extreme, even if the troll’s chance of winning were essentially 0%, the target could still rationally pay a positive settlement to avoid having to finance its own litigation expenses.

Bargaining and settlement Settlement bargaining is driven by the parties’ outside options if they do not settle. The troll’s credible threat is: “If you do not settle, you will incur litigation costs (and possibly lose).” Fee shifting weakens that threat because it improves the target’s outside option (going to court is cheaper when you expect to win), while also worsening the troll’s outside option (if the troll loses, it may have to pay the target’s costs). Stricter patentability further weakens the threat by lowering the troll’s plausible probability of prevailing, so the troll has less bargaining leverage.

A simple numerical illustration: suppose a lawsuit would generate legal expenses of 1 (in round units) for each side. If Norway’s loser-pays rule applies and the target’s chance of losing is \(1-p=0.1\), then the target’s expected cost from litigating is about \(0.1 \times 2 = 0.2\) (it pays both sides’ costs only when it loses, and pays roughly 0 when it wins). In an each-party-pays system, the target expects to pay its own 1 even if it wins, so it may accept settlements approaching 1 simply to avoid that certain expense. This makes settlement extraction much easier in the US setting.

Real costs and benefits

  • Litigation and attorney resources: Loser-pays and stricter patents reduce troll-driven filings and therefore reduce wasteful litigation expenditures relative to an each-party-pays, weaker-patent environment.
  • Expected misallocation of firm resources (avoidance and delay): When trolls have stronger settlement leverage, targets spend more real resources on precautionary redesign, delaying launches, or diverting management time; weaker troll leverage reduces these distortions.
  • Administrative and screening resources in patent granting: Stricter patent requirements typically require more resources up front (examination, documentation), increasing administrative costs, but can reduce downstream troll activity and litigation.
  • Expected error costs (granting/enforcing low-quality patents): Weaker patent standards increase the risk that low-quality or overly broad patents survive long enough to support credible threats; stricter standards reduce this expected harm.

Note that settlement payments themselves are transfers and are not counted as real resource costs. They matter here because they drive incentives: higher expected settlement revenue attracts trolls; lower expected settlement revenue discourages entry.

Conditional conclusion Patent trolling should be less prevalent in Norway than in the US if (i) loser-pays is applied in a way that makes “winning” close to costless for a firm that expects to win, and (ii) stricter patentability requirements materially lower trolls’ probability of prevailing, so targets’ expected loss risk is small. Under these conditions, targets are unwilling to pay large settlements, while trolls face higher expected downside from losing (including paying the opponent’s costs), so trolling becomes less profitable. If instead fee shifting were weak in practice, or patents were easier to obtain and enforce (raising the troll’s chance of winning), the US-style settlement leverage would increase and troll activity would be expected to rise.

▶ Question 38: BankID Fraud Complaints Board

The bank may refuse to cover the loss if it believes that a victim of BankID fraud has acted negligently. The customer may then bring the case before the Norwegian Financial Services Complaints Board (Finansklagenemnda). The scheme is free of charge, written, and far simpler and faster than a lawsuit, and therefore entails lower costs for the parties. Using economic theory, explain how such a simplified system may affect the outcomes of disputes between banks and customers, compared with a situation in which the customer would have to sue the bank in the courts.

▶ What a Good Answer Should Contain

A good answer should use Legal Incentives Model. Good answers could also draw on Cost–Benefit Analysis. The key economic mechanism is that simplifying dispute resolution lowers the private cost of pursuing a claim, which changes the customer’s expected value of escalating the dispute and therefore the credibility of the “I will take this further” threat. Because outside options determine bargaining power, the cheaper forum can shift negotiated settlements and the frequency with which banks choose to settle rather than fight. Strong answers also recognize that the direction of the settlement effect is not mechanically determined: lower costs can shrink the “stakes” of litigation, but asymmetries in risk aversion, delay costs, and reputational incentives can push outcomes in the opposite direction.

▶ Example solution

To answer this question we will use Legal Incentives Model and Cost–Benefit Analysis, focusing on how the dispute-resolution forum changes parties’ expected payoffs and therefore bargaining outcomes.

Object and counterfactual The object is a simplified, low-cost complaint mechanism (Finansklagenemnda) for BankID-fraud disputes where the bank denies coverage due to alleged customer negligence. The counterfactual is that the customer must sue the bank in ordinary courts, with a slower and more expensive procedure.

Actors and decision margin The key actors are the customer (fraud victim) and the bank. The relevant margins are (i) whether the customer escalates the dispute, and (ii) whether the bank offers settlement (and at what level) versus refusing and forcing adjudication.

Incentives and behavioral responses With the Legal Incentives Model logic, a customer escalates if the expected value of the process is positive. A cheaper and simpler forum increases the customer’s expected value of escalating by reducing expected process costs, making escalation (and therefore settlement threats) more credible.

Numerical illustration (credible threat): Assume court litigation costs NOK 20,000 for each party, while the complaint board process costs NOK 5,000 for each party (e.g., time, documentation, internal legal handling). The loss is NOK 25,000 and the customer wins with probability 60%. If the loser pays both parties’ costs, then in court the customer’s expected value is \[ 25{,}000 \times 0.6 - 40{,}000 \times 0.4 = -1{,}000. \] Even with a 60% chance of winning, suing is not privately worthwhile, so the threat to sue is not credible. Anticipating this, the bank can more safely ignore the customer’s demand.

In the complaint board the same logic gives \[ 25{,}000 \times 0.6 - 10{,}000 \times 0.4 = 11{,}000, \] so escalating is privately attractive. The threat to take the case to the board is credible, which pushes the bank toward settlement.

A direct implication is that lower dispute costs let more customers get their case heard (or obtain settlement), especially when the disputed amount is modest and the probability of winning is only moderate.

Real costs and benefits

  • Dispute-resolution resource costs (administration, lawyers, time): Lower under the complaint board than in court (fewer procedural steps; written process; faster), so fewer real resources are spent per case.
  • Delay costs (time value, stress, disrupted consumption/investment): Likely lower under the faster forum, reducing real waiting costs for customers and case-handling costs for banks.
  • Error costs (wrong outcomes due to simplified process): Ambiguous. Simplification can increase error if fact-finding is weaker, but it can also reduce error if more cases are actually processed rather than dropped because litigation is too costly.
  • Precaution and compliance costs (anti-fraud effort by customers and banks): Ambiguous. Easier recovery can reduce customers’ incentives to be careful (a moral-hazard channel), but a higher expected chance that the bank must reimburse can increase the bank’s incentives to invest in fraud prevention and better authentication procedures.
  • Strategic expenditure costs (rent-seeking in procedure): Lower procedural complexity can reduce wasteful spending on tactics aimed at raising the other side’s costs.

Transfers such as the reimbursement amount (who pays the NOK 25,000 loss) are not counted as real costs or benefits in Cost–Benefit Analysis, but they matter for incentives because they shift the parties’ private payoffs and thus their willingness to escalate and settle.

Bargaining and settlement Lower process costs change each side’s outside option (what happens if bargaining fails), which affects settlement. Using the same “loser pays costs” assumption, suppose the customer has an 80% chance of winning and the disputed amount remains NOK 25,000.

Court:

  • Customer’s lowest acceptable settlement (expected value of going to court):

\[ 25{,}000 \times 0.8 - 40{,}000 \times 0.2 = 12{,}000. \]

  • Bank’s highest willingness to pay (expected cost if it refuses settlement):

\[ 25{,}000 \times 0.8 + 40{,}000 \times 0.8 = 52{,}000. \]

  • Under Nash bargaining (splitting the bargaining range), settlement is

\[ (12{,}000 + 52{,}000)/2 = 32{,}000. \]

Complaint board:

  • Customer’s lowest acceptable settlement:

\[ 25{,}000 \times 0.8 - 10{,}000 \times 0.2 = 18{,}000. \]

  • Bank’s highest willingness to pay:

\[ 25{,}000 \times 0.8 + 10{,}000 \times 0.8 = 28{,}000. \]

  • Nash bargaining settlement:

\[ (18{,}000 + 28{,}000)/2 = 23{,}000. \]

In this example, the more expensive court system produces a higher settlement for the customer because when the customer is more likely than not to win, “loser pays” makes the bank’s expected loss from trial large (it expects to pay both the loss and the high litigation costs with high probability). Lower-cost adjudication reduces these stakes and can mechanically pull the settlement amount down, even as it makes escalation more credible.

Other factors can push in the opposite direction and improve the customer’s outcome under the simplified system:

  • Risk aversion: Customers are plausibly more risk-averse than banks. Higher litigation costs increase the size of the “bad state” (losing and paying costs), which can further weaken the customer’s bargaining position in the court system.
  • Patience / delay: A slower court process harms customers more if they need the money quickly, again weakening their bargaining position in the court system.
  • Reputation effects: The bank may act “tough” in individual cases to deter future complaints, which can reduce settlement offers even when the customer’s legal position is strong.

Conditional conclusion A simplified complaint mechanism is likely to increase the number of disputes that are pursued and the number that settle, because lower process costs make the customer’s escalation threat more credible (positive expected value for more customers). The effect on the size of settlements is theoretically ambiguous: holding fixed beliefs, cost shifting, and bargaining structure, lower costs can reduce the settlement amount by lowering the stakes; but if customers are more risk-averse, more liquidity constrained, or more harmed by delay, the simplified and faster process can still improve customer outcomes relative to courts. The net effect therefore depends on (i) the cost difference, (ii) the probability of customer success, (iii) cost-shifting rules in each forum, and (iv) asymmetries in risk, delay, and reputational incentives.

Firms and Markets

Corporate Governance

Foundations used:

  • Legal Incentives Model
  • Information, Evidence, and Verifiability
  • Transaction Costs
  • Designing Contracts

Learning goal: apply economic reasoning to analyze corporate governance mechanisms as responses to agency problems inside firms.

Types of Questions You Should Be Able to Answer

  • How should corporate governance mechanisms be designed to address agency problems?
  • Why does limited liability weaken deterrence in corporate law?
  • What are the limits of corporate law in controlling managerial opportunism?

Modern economic activity is organized largely through corporations. Decisions about investment, risk-taking, compensation, and control are made within firms that pool capital from many investors and separate ownership from control. How these organizations are governed therefore has profound consequences for firm performance, market efficiency, and economic growth.

This separation of ownership and control creates agency problems. Managers or controlling shareholders may pursue private interests that diverge from the interests of residual claimants. Corporate law and corporate governance shape the incentives of managers, shareholders, and boards by determining who has authority to make decisions, how conflicts of interest are handled, how information is disclosed, and how misconduct is constrained.

From a business perspective, corporate law affects how firms raise capital, how they are monitored, and how strategic decisions are made under conditions of imperfect information and limited accountability. Well-designed governance systems make productive cooperation possible and channel effort toward value creation. Poorly designed systems allow opportunism, entrenchment, and excessive risk-taking.

This chapter uses economic reasoning to study corporate law and corporate governance as responses to agency problems inside the firm. The focus is not on doctrine, but on incentives: how governance structures influence behavior, how legal rules affect the probability and consequences of misconduct, and why agency problems persist even when formal legal protections exist.

Why Corporations Exist

Many economically valuable activities require large, long-term investments and the coordination of many participants. Pooling capital from multiple investors and delegating decision-making to specialized managers makes it possible to undertake projects that would be infeasible for individuals acting alone.

The corporate form facilitates this by allowing investors to contribute capital in exchange for transferable shares, while authority over day-to-day decisions is concentrated in managers or controlling owners. This separation of ownership from control enables economies of scale, specialization, and risk diversification.

From an economic perspective, the corporation can be understood as a governance structure that reduces transaction costs. Instead of relying on detailed contracts among all participants, the corporate form centralizes decision-making and provides standardized rules for control and profit sharing when contracts are incomplete.

At the same time, the features that make corporations attractive also create tensions between control and accountability. Understanding how these tensions arise, and how corporate law responds to them, is the focus of the next section.

Agency Problems in Corporations

The separation of ownership and control that characterizes the corporate form creates agency problems. Shareholders (aksjonærer) provide capital and bear the residual risk of the firm, but delegate decision-making authority to managers or controlling shareholders whose interests may diverge from maximizing firm value.

From an economic perspective, an agency problem (prinsipal–agent-problem) arises whenever the party who makes decisions does not bear the full consequences of those decisions. In corporations, those in control may enjoy private benefits that are not shared with other investors, while a significant share of the costs is borne by the firm or by dispersed shareholders.

These private benefits can take many forms.
